item.title: Ubisoft Announces A Brutal New Restructuring With More Investment In Gen AI And Further Job Cuts
item.content:encoded:
The French publisher behind Far Cry and Assassin‚Äôs Creed is planning even more cuts, delays, and pivots as part of a brutal new restructuring. Ubisoft announced on Thursday that a company-wide reset will include a new creative structure, ‚Äúrightsizing of the organization,‚Äù and more investment in things like ‚Äúplayer-facing Generative AI.‚Äù

The latest shifts come amid challenging five-year stretch for Ubisoft where big blockbusters like Assassin‚Äôs Creed Valhalla and Far Cry 6 were few and far between while big bets like Star Wars Outlaws and xDefiant failed to pay off. In its January 21 earnings press release, the company promised a ‚Äúradically new value-creation model‚Äù based around a ‚Äúmore gamer-centric organization.‚Äù This will include ‚Äúbusiness units with faster, decentralized decision-making and a greater ability to quickly adapt to players‚Äô expectations‚Äù and a ‚Äúrightsized and more agile organization, delivering improved structural efficiencies over time.‚Äù

A management consultant company like McKinsey & Company couldn‚Äôt have written it better. For those not versed in 21st century corpo-speak, that means a slow disassembly of the global AAA factory Ubisoft spent the 2010s building up and more studio closures and layoffs. The move will also include delays of many big games and the cancellation of others like the Prince of Persia remake that‚Äôs been in development for years.



https://kotaku.com/ubisoft-earnings-layoffs-delays-canceled-ai-2000661869

item.title: Mio: Memories In Orbit: The Kotaku Review
item.content:encoded:
Mio: Memories in Orbit is a reminder that games can be all killer, no filler, for better or worse. A stylish side-scrolling Metroidvania, Mio marches to a familiar beat and wraps things up well before it could potentially grow tiresome. Its world is alluringly illustrated, and its gallery of rogues and weird little robots have their charms. Despite that, I do wish there was a bit more going on in its composition. I wish it felt denser and more layered. I‚Äôd have appreciated a bit more variety in instrumentation. I wish its lyricism hooked me more. And in the absence of these things, I found I kind of missed the filler, the noise that could have been constructed around that central, thrumming beat. 

The first thing one is likely to clock about Mio is how gorgeous it is. It‚Äôs very easy to stop and stare at the landscapes in the background of nearly every one of its scenes. The Vessel, the spaceship on which Mio takes place, recalls the hostile and beautiful alien world of Scavengers Reign. It‚Äôs (almost) never as trippy, but it does often feel as dangerous. One second you‚Äôll be in a lush, vegetative, and deadly jungle with strong purple hues and the next you‚Äôll be in an azure metropolis that appears to have frozen over. Regardless of where you are, though, Mio is a stunner to look at, and its visuals are half the reason I explored the Vessel as deeply as I could. 

Mio‚Äòs movement: Solid fundamentals, not enough evolution

The other reason to play Mio is because it feels really damn good. Metroidvanias emphasize exploration, but it‚Äôd be no fun to move and fight through them if the game felt sluggish and if the combat were so-so. Luckily, Mio nails the fundamentals out of the gate. It‚Äôs got all the tricks one might hope for up its sleeve: a double jump that looks more like an elegant mid-air pirouette, a hookshot used for both platforming and shooting yourself across arenas in combat, an instantaneous dodge move that feels almost as satisfying as a Sekiro parry, a reliably weighty (and expressively animated) combo string, and more. 

This mixture of silky-smooth movement and combat abilities most prominently figures into Mio‚Äòs solid boss battles. Though none of the ones I ran into ever ran away with the show‚Äìthere are plenty of hidden encounters along the game‚Äôs periphery, as well as the route to the game‚Äôs secret ending‚ÄìI still had plenty of fun with each of them. Whether they were a drill-nosed mole creature burrowing into the arena or a mechanical murder doll complete with a saber and laser gun, each was stylistically distinct and demanded that I learn how to best use Mio‚Äòs movement tech to navigate their numerous hazards long enough to see and capitalize on an attack window. 

I did, at times, find myself wishing that some of these encounters and arenas stood apart more. While the bosses never tread the same ground aesthetically, most of the stages themselves felt pretty same-y and the fights hit a lot of the same notes. At the end of the day, most of the arenas were square rooms with a few grapple points (save for one notable exception that breaks from this rhythm of boss fights) and most of these fights were one-on-one duels. Very few of the boss fights I did see featured environmental hazards and traps that could complicate matters and present interesting new wrinkles, and I would‚Äôve preferred more of that variation throughout. 

Maybe I‚Äôm just a masochist who really likes punishing games like Silksong and its ilk, but one thing those games I love get really right is their variety and breadth of enemies and encounters, and that sort of spice is sadly missing from Mio. Considering the lengths that Mio goes to in order to feel adjacent to the Souls lineage‚Äìthere are bonfire-like checkpoints here, and more than enough enigmatic worldbuilding to go around‚Äìit‚Äôs a bit of a shame it doesn‚Äôt go that step further, especially on the game‚Äôs most obvious and critical path.

Speaking of a lack of variety, I was disappointed in how little Mio‚Äòs combat ever grows. There are modifications you can make that alter certain attributes, like one upgrade that allows Mio to do a heavy attack immediately after landing a hookshot, but besides that, you never earn new techniques or weapons. There is no additional combo to learn by traveling off the beaten path. There is no projectile with which to occasionally pepper an enemy from afar. 

Samus has missiles to complement her pea shooter. Castlevania‚Äòs numerous protagonists can begin the game with a great variety of weapons, like axes, swords, or whips. Mega Man absorbs the powers of the robot masters he defeats. Juan of Guacamelee gains entirely new wrestling techniques and Ori regularly picks up stunning new magical powers. The Knight of Hollow Knight can use charge attacks as well as a highly-effective magic blast and a dive move with a massive area-of-effect, and Hornet gains new traps, tools, and crests that fundamentally alter her moveset. 

By comparison, Mio is stuck with their same little saber and three-attack combo for the entirety of the game. The lack of imagination here doesn‚Äôt significantly take away from the game, but I did find myself less enthused with the prospect of combat in Mio‚Äòs late stretches, in large part because it had plateaued so early. 

A mystery without mystique

And while I‚Äôm speaking of aspects of the game that regrettably fall flat, I really wish Mio‚Äôs narrative went‚Ä¶anywhere. The Vessel is an ark ship meant to ferry a colony and their robots (who look a lot like Pascal from Nier: Automata and fill the ranks of the game‚Äôs cast) across the stars in search of a new world. Partway through the journey though, the Voices‚ÄîAI that served as deities and guides to the robots and are named after body parts like the Spine and the Hand‚Äîcease function, allowing the Vessel and its inhabitants to fall into disrepair as the ship drifts. The great mystery of the game is figuring out what exactly happened to cause the AIs to stop and go quiet.

Despite its early promise, though, Mio‚Äòs writing just didn‚Äôt hook me. The game‚Äôs story is largely explained in lore tomes found through exploration and following the game‚Äôs main story path, but even these missives fail to inject the proceedings with a sense of urgency or dramatic tension. Normally, I‚Äôd fear that I just don‚Äôt get the story, but in the case of Mio, I do, save for whatever revelations the game‚Äôs out-of-the way ‚Äútrue‚Äù ending might hold. However, the morsels of story that Mio delivered never quite lived up to the mystique that it spent so long building up, and I found myself quite disappointed in the answers and resolutions afforded to the conflicts and characters by the tale‚Äôs end.

  • Back-of-the-box quote:

    ‚ÄúLo-fi beats to Metroid to.‚Äù

  • developer:

    Douze Dixi√®mes

  • type of game:

    Metroidvania

  • Liked:

    Arresting visual style, fluid combat and movement, really fun boss battles.

  • Disliked:

    Story fails to build any momentum, lack of variety in combat.

  • Platforms:

    PC (played on), PS5, Xbox Series X/S, Nintendo Switch 2, Nintendo Switch.

  • Release date:

    January 20, 2026

  • Played:

    Rolled credits at about 17 hours, but spent about 20+ hours working towards the secret ending before moving on.

Its characters, what little there are in settings like Metropolis and the Haven, feel like one-note bit players in the game‚Äôs grander machinations. The Voices themselves are less pronounced throughout the story than I‚Äôd hoped for. Even Mio‚Äòs allies fail to leap off the page. Despite my initial efforts to see as much of the game as possible and give it the chance to change my mind, I simply could not feign any more interest in securing a more hopeful resolution to the ills of a cast that felt so amorphous and under-developed. 

Suffice it to say, Mio doesn‚Äôt quite tick off all the boxes of what I‚Äôm looking for in a Metroidvania. It‚Äôs got mystery and intrigue enough to incentivize you to look in corners and dart around its imaginatively rendered sci-fi utopia gone awry, but not quite enough to pay off the threads it establishes early on. Mio‚Äôs middle action is defined by a great run of abilities that make cutting a path through the Vessel a joy in the moment, as well as bosses that pose an admirable challenge despite their humdrum layouts. But as the journey comes to a close, the sameness of its encounters and simplistic combat closes out the story on a bit of a whimper where a bang might‚Äôve felt more appropriate. 

Mio is stylish and elegant to boot, but that and a decent grasp of the fundamentals are not enough to deepen my appreciation of what‚Äôs ultimately a pretty by-the-numbers Metroidvania. It‚Äôs an adherent to the form, but I rarely like the tune it sings, and don‚Äôt quite love it despite my efforts to. 



https://kotaku.com/mio-memories-in-orbit-review-metroidvania-ps5-switch-2000661850
item.dc:creator: invalid@example.com (ResetEra_Newsbot

item.title: Game Trailer Showcased By IGN Slammed For Using AI ‚ÄòPlaceholders‚Äô
item.content:encoded:
‚ÄúHell is empty and all the devils are here.‚Äù That quote from Shakespeare‚Äôs The Tempest is how the debut trailer for hack-and-slash adventure game Fallen begins. It was accurate if you count among those devils the scourge of AI slop. The trailer, an IGN exclusive, was flamed on social media for appearing to showcase gen AI work, and the developer of the game later confirmed it.

The Fallen trailer appeared on X on Monday where it immediately made a splash far beyond what you might have expected from its otherwise generic-looking, demon-slaying gameplay. ‚ÄúIntroducing Fallen, a new Xbox 360-era inspired character action game where you play as Astra, a fallen angel who must battle through Hell and its demonic forces. It‚Äôs in development for console and PC,‚Äù read the marketing copy.

But what stood out to people immediately was the now familiar whiff of slick but lifeless gen AI-produced art that was peppered throughout the trailer. ‚ÄúIt looks nauseatingly bad, genAI isn‚Äôt just walking back gaming hardware, it‚Äôs trying to make the games themselves awful too,‚Äù wrote cosplayer Kitty Bit. ‚ÄúThis is the most AI ass AI video game I ever did see lmao,‚Äù wrote Twitch streamer Ms5000watts. ‚ÄúLooks like a weird amalgamation of AI and jank,‚Äù read one of the top YouTube comments. 

They aren't even trying to hide it brahüò≠üò≠AI slop content is off the charts now https://t.co/uWFQdopCy8 pic.twitter.com/b0B9Jnm8aq

‚Äî Oshbard (@Ludvicus) January 19, 2026

Was this another example of people being paranoid about gen AI and jumping the gun with the accusations of slop? Nope! Superboo Studios founder, director, producer, and writer Brooke Burgess admitted as much after the backlash, but claimed the gameplay was real and in-engine UE5.4 work. Burgess blamed ‚Äúcontext‚Äù collapse for the controversy.

‚ÄúWhat ended up being shared as an ‚Äòofficial trailer‚Äô was actually our early dev ‚Äòtone pitch‚Äô, i.e., a work-in-progress UE5 teaser designed for funding discussions,‚Äù he told TheGamer. ‚ÄúThere are [AI-Generated] placeholders in there, specifically some 2D test assets used to explore mood and presentation (for example, how ‚Äòlost souls‚Äô and fallen angels in the game might react when spoken to and judged, along w/ WIP HUD elements). That material was never intended as final content, nor as a statement on how the shipped game would be made.‚Äù

To go back to referencing Shakespeare for a moment, Burgess seems to be suggesting that ‚Äúthe fault, dear Brutus, is not in our ‚Äòtone pitch AI placeholders,‚Äô but in ourselves.‚Äù He makes it sound like IGN posted the wrong trailer, or jumped the gun. In actuality, Burgess has had no qualms about using AI slop to pitch the game to potential investors.

In fact, he recently complained about just how hard it is to raise money for making a game right now. Burgess said every publisher he‚Äôs spoken to is asking how he‚Äôll us AI to streamline development. He‚Äôs open to using it for QA and localization, but claims he‚Äôs not ‚Äúwaving the flag of AI by any stretch.‚Äù but claims he‚Äôs not ‚Äúwaving the flag of AI by any stretch.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not going to sell my soul and be like, ‚ÄòYeah, I‚Äôll do it by myself, let me prompt this whole game into existence,'‚Äù he recently told GamesIndustry.Biz. ‚ÄúNo, I want to work with really talented people and make something cool. But if integrating it in a way that doesn‚Äôt affect creativity, but helps to save a little bit of money and gets the game out there to people, and gives us a chance to make something cool and memorable, and then make something else after that‚Äìit‚Äôs something I have to factor in.‚Äù



https://kotaku.com/game-trailer-showcased-by-ign-slammed-for-using-ai-placeholders-2000661829
item.dc:creator: invalid@example.com (ResetEra_Newsbot

item.title: This Jackery Portable Power Station Just Fell Even Further Overnight to a New All-Time Low
item.content:encoded:
The Jackery Explorer 300 Portable Power Station provides a convenient means to keep mobile devices and campsite accessories powered when they‚Äôre not near an electrical outlet. It is a rectangular-shaped unit with a built-in handle and weighs approximately 7.1 pounds, making it easy to transport to other areas within the home or pack into the car. The chassis contains a rechargeable 293Wh Lithium-Ion battery that provides adequate power for a variety of small devices during short-duration power outages or camping adventures.

Purchase the Jackery Explorer 300 Portable Power Station from Amazon for $179, down from $259, which is a discount of $80 and 31%.

See at Amazon

A power station that can keep you juiced up no matter the situation

The Jackery Explorer 300 Portable Power Station has two AC outlets, allowing you to use standard home-type plugs. You can operate a small fan or light, or a laptop, while leaving the second outlet available for additional equipment. The AC output is designed for consistent operation of devices such as these, and should perform well for backup applications and weekend excursions where continuous wall-type power is desired.

In addition to the AC outlets, the Jackery Explorer 300 Portable Power Station offers multiple USB-C, USB-A, and a single 12-Volt automobile-style port for connecting other various devices. With the ability to simultaneously charge multiple device types, you can avoid having to rotate a single device at a time. Additionally, because all charging ports are on the front panel, you can easily identify and manage their cables and determine which devices are currently connected and charging.

Recharging the Jackery Explorer 300 Portable Power Station is also highly versatile. Regarding power sources for recharging this unit, you can use wall AC power, automobile power, or solar power from a separate panel. Because this unit supports fast charging, you can quickly recharge the battery to nearly full capacity in a couple of hours, thereby minimizing downtime.

The power station is relatively compact and designed to fit inside a closet, cabinet, or RV storage compartment when not in use. Its rounded edges and sturdy carrying handle make it easy to transport this unit wherever needed. Additionally, because the unit operates silently and emits no harmful emissions, it can be stored closer to the point of use rather than farther away from where it is intended to be used.

All you need to begin using the Jackery Explorer 300 Portable Power Station after the unit has been fully recharged is included with the purchase. Included with the purchase is the portable power station itself, the AC adapter for wall power, the car charging cable for charging on the go, and the user manual. Once you have identified which devices are essential to you and plugged them in, the power station‚Äôs compact size and flexible charging options make it a solid backup unit on sale for $179, down from its usual price of $259.

See at Amazon



https://kotaku.com/this-jackery-portable-power-station-just-fell-even-further-overnight-to-a-new-all-time-low-2000661436
